elements.content: Erbium fumarate [Er2(fum)3(H2O)4]·8H2O, 1, (fum = fumarate dianion) crystallizes at room temperature in a silica gel column. The structure is three-dimensional and consists of layers of erbium fumarate pillared by fumarate dianions acting in the bis-chelating mode. The layers contain arrays of erbium cations bridged by fumarate dianions acting in the bis-bidentate bridging mode. The relatively large channels formed in the direction of the a and c axes are filled by water molecules that form a hydrogen bonded layer, comprising cyclic hexamers with both boat and chair conformations and cyclic decamers with boat−chair−boat conformation. The water molecules are reversibly removed at 90 °C. The evacuated metal−organic framework, 2, is stable up to 400 °C. Both compounds 1 and 2 exhibit weak antiferromagnetic interactions.
elements.clean_text: Erbium fumarate [Er2(fum)3(H2O)4]⋅8H2O, 1, (fum = fumarate dianion) crystallizes at room temperature in a silica gel column. The structure is three-dimensional and consists of layers of erbium fumarate pillared by fumarate dianions acting in the bis-chelating mode. The layers contain arrays of erbium cations bridged by fumarate dianions acting in the bis-bidentate bridging mode. The relatively large channels formed in the direction of the a and c axes are filled by water molecules that form a hydrogen bonded layer, comprising cyclic hexamers with both boat and chair conformations and cyclic decamers with boat-chair-boat conformation. The water molecules are reversibly removed at 90 °C. The evacuated metal-organic framework, 2, is stable up to 400 °C. Both compounds 1 and 2 exhibit weak antiferromagnetic interactions.

elements.content: [Er2(fum)3(H2O)4]·8H2O consists of planar layers of cadmium fumarate pillared by fumaric acid. The enclatrated water molecules form hexamers with both chair and boat conformation and cyclic decamers with boat−chair−boat conformation. Water is reversibly removed at 90 °C.
elements.clean_text: [Er2(fum)3(H2O)4]⋅8H2O consists of planar layers of cadmium fumarate pillared by fumaric acid. The enclatrated water molecules form hexamers with both chair and boat conformation and cyclic decamers with boat-chair-boat conformation. Water is reversibly removed at 90 °C.

elements.content: The construction of metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) with open architecture is a challenging topic in modern solid-state supramolecular chemistry. In this context, polycarboxylic ligands constitute an interesting family of organic building blocks because of the many coordination modes of the carboxylic groups. In particular, the bridging ability of this functional group favors the formation of cluster-like solids suitable for cooperative magnetic interactions or even electrical conduction. Furthermore, the chelating ability of the carboxylic group may contribute to the thermal stability, which is a crucial issue for this class of solids. Finally, the acidity determines the amount of ionized carboxylic groups, and therefore a variety of crystal architectures are expected to be produced by varying the pH of the milieu from which crystals grow. It was shown recently that polymerization of aliphatic4b,5 or aromatic4a,6 polycarboxylic acids, in the presence of rare earth cations, is a promising route to construct MOFs with open architecture. Rare earth coordination solids are also of potential interest in molecular magnetism5c,7 and luminesence.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The construction of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with open architecture is a challenging topic in modern solid-state supramolecular chemistry. In this context, polycarboxylic ligands constitute an interesting family of organic building blocks because of the many coordination modes of the carboxylic groups. In particular, the bridging ability of this functional group favors the formation of cluster-like solids suitable for cooperative magnetic interactions or even electrical conduction. Furthermore, the chelating ability of the carboxylic group may contribute to the thermal stability, which is a crucial issue for this class of solids. Finally, the acidity determines the amount of ionized carboxylic groups, and therefore a variety of crystal architectures are expected to be produced by varying the pH of the milieu from which crystals grow. It was shown recently that polymerization of aliphatic4b,5 or aromatic4a,6 polycarboxylic acids, in the presence of rare earth cations, is a promising route to construct MOFs with open architecture. Rare earth coordination solids are also of potential interest in molecular magnetism5c,7 and luminesence.

elements.content: As in the case of inorganic zeolites, the porous coordination solids crystallize by enclathrating solvent molecules within the pores. It is widely accepted that both solvent−framework and solvent−solvent interactions are important for the stability (and the nature) of the framework obtained. Thus, the structure of the enclathrated solvent is an important parameter for understanding the mechanism of formation of such complex supramolecular solid-state edifices. Moreover, in the case where water is the solvent, the structure of the enclathrated water might provide insight into the structure of liquid water or ice. A variety of water clusters have been recently studied theoretically or experimentally. Some of them postulated to exist in the bulk water were found recently in some molecular solids containing channels or cavities.
elements.clean_text: As in the case of inorganic zeolites, the porous coordination solids crystallize by enclathrating solvent molecules within the pores. It is widely accepted that both solvent-framework and solvent-solvent interactions are important for the stability (and the nature) of the framework obtained. Thus, the structure of the enclathrated solvent is an important parameter for understanding the mechanism of formation of such complex supramolecular solid-state edifices. Moreover, in the case where water is the solvent, the structure of the enclathrated water might provide insight into the structure of liquid water or ice. A variety of water clusters have been recently studied theoretically or experimentally. Some of them postulated to exist in the bulk water were found recently in some molecular solids containing channels or cavities.

elements.content: In this work, we used an unsaturated ligand, namely, fumaric acid and Er3+ cations to construct a neutral microporous coordination solid. The choice of fumaric acid was motivated by the potential ability of this ligand to promote magnetic interactions between paramagnetic centers. The structure of this complex12 and of some isostructural ones with different lanthanides, have been previously reported, mainly from the viewpoint of a classical crystal structure report. In this work, we describe the unique architecture of the 2D polymeric water network, enclathrated in the channels of this material. This network is composed of hexamers with both boat and chair conformations and of cyclic decamers with boat−chair−boat (BCB) conformation, appearing for the first time. Moreover, we show that the structure of the water network is intimately related to the structure of the MOF.
elements.clean_text: In this work, we used an unsaturated ligand, namely, fumaric acid and Er3+ cations to construct a neutral microporous coordination solid. The choice of fumaric acid was motivated by the potential ability of this ligand to promote magnetic interactions between paramagnetic centers. The structure of this complex12 and of some isostructural ones with different lanthanides, have been previously reported, mainly from the viewpoint of a classical crystal structure report. In this work, we describe the unique architecture of the 2D polymeric water network, enclathrated in the channels of this material. This network is composed of hexamers with both boat and chair conformations and of cyclic decamers with boat-chair-boat (BCB) conformation, appearing for the first time. Moreover, we show that the structure of the water network is intimately related to the structure of the MOF.

elements.content: [Er 2 (fum) 3 (H 2 O) 4 ]·8H 2 O (1) . Single crystals were obtained by diffusing an aqueous solution of 0.007 M erbium nitrate in a silica gel column containing the ligand (0.01 M) at pH approximately 6. The test tube containing the reacting system was left open, and, after several weeks, upon complete evaporation of the liquid phase, one single crystal of pink color was formed. The composition of the crystal was deduced from X-ray crystallography. The same crystalline phase was easily prepared in powder form by mixing 30 mL of 0.1 M fumaric acid at pH 6.1 with 20 mL of 0.1 M erbium nitrate. The final pH was approximately 5. The pink precipitate was washed with distilled water and left to dry in air. The experimental XRPD pattern was in good agreement with that simulated from the single crystal data. Elemental analysis calcd (%) for 1 in powder form:  C 16.13, H 3.36; found:  C 16.18, H 3.39.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 [Er  2  (fum)  3  (H  2  O)  4  ]⋅8H  2  O (1) . Single crystals were obtained by diffusing an aqueous solution of 0.007 M erbium nitrate in a silica gel column containing the ligand (0.01 M) at pH approximately 6. The test tube containing the reacting system was left open, and, after several weeks, upon complete evaporation of the liquid phase, one single crystal of pink color was formed. The composition of the crystal was deduced from X-ray crystallography. The same crystalline phase was easily prepared in powder form by mixing 30 mL of 0.1 M fumaric acid at pH 6.1 with 20 mL of 0.1 M erbium nitrate. The final pH was approximately 5. The pink precipitate was washed with distilled water and left to dry in air. The experimental XRPD pattern was in good agreement with that simulated from the single crystal data. Elemental analysis calcd (%) for 1 in powder form: C 16.13, H 3.36; found: C 16.18, H 3.39.

elements.content:
Er 2 (fum) 3 · x H 2 O (0 < x <1.5) (2). This compound of pink color was formed by heating 1 at 90 °C for about 1.30 h, in air.

Sorption Experiments. A small amount (approximately 150 mg) of compound 2 was placed in a glass beaker containing about 20 mL of water or ethanol. The beaker was covered and left to react overnight, under stirring. The precipitate was recovered by filtration and left to dry in air for about 5 days. In the case of water, the resulting product was compound 1. Elemental analysis calcd (%):  C 16.13, H 3.36; found:  C 16.17, H 3.88. In the case of ethanol, compound 3 of the formula Er2(fum)3·4.5H2O was obtained. Elemental analysis calcd (%):  C 19.00, H 1.98; found:  C 18.32, H 2.18. A weight loss of 10.73% was observed in thermogravimetric analysis of this compound (calcd 10.68%). In the case of water vapor sorption, 150 mg of 2 were placed in a glass watch and put in a desiccator, near a beaker containing 30 mL of water. The desiccator was closed and the system was left to react for about 2 days. In these conditions, compound 1 was obtained. Elemental analysis calcd (%):  C 16.13, H 3.36; found:  C 16.22, H 3.74.

Er  2  (fum)  3  ⋅  x  H  2  O (0 <   x   <1.5) (2). This compound of pink color was formed by heating 1 at 90 °C for about 1.30 h, in air. 

 Sorption Experiments. A small amount (approximately 150 mg) of compound 2 was placed in a glass beaker containing about 20 mL of water or ethanol. The beaker was covered and left to react overnight, under stirring. The precipitate was recovered by filtration and left to dry in air for about 5 days. In the case of water, the resulting product was compound 1. Elemental analysis calcd (%): C 16.13, H 3.36; found: C 16.17, H 3.88. In the case of ethanol, compound 3 of the formula Er2(fum)3⋅4.5H2O was obtained. Elemental analysis calcd (%): C 19.00, H 1.98; found: C 18.32, H 2.18. A weight loss of 10.73% was observed in thermogravimetric analysis of this compound (calcd 10.68%). In the case of water vapor sorption, 150 mg of 2 were placed in a glass watch and put in a desiccator, near a beaker containing 30 mL of water. The desiccator was closed and the system was left to react for about 2 days. In these conditions, compound 1 was obtained. Elemental analysis calcd (%): C 16.13, H 3.36; found: C 16.22, H 3.74.

elements.content: X-ray Crystallography. The X-ray diffraction intensities for compound 1 were collected at room temperature on a Bruker P4 diffractometer, employing graphite monochromated MoKa radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The structure was solved by using direct methods and refined on F 2 using SHELXL97. All hydrogen atoms of the ligand were located and their positional parameters refined. Most of the water hydrogen atoms were located from the difference Fourier maps, but it was not possible to refine their positional parameters. This is due to the disorder inherent to this type of structure. Indeed, multiple weak electron density maxima were found around the water oxygen atoms. XRPD data were collected at room temperature on a Bruker D8 Advanced System with monochromatic Cu radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å).
elements.clean_text: X-ray Crystallography. The X-ray diffraction intensities for compound 1 were collected at room temperature on a Bruker P4 diffractometer, employing graphite monochromated MoKa radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The structure was solved by using direct methods and refined on F 2 using SHELXL97. All hydrogen atoms of the ligand were located and their positional parameters refined. Most of the water hydrogen atoms were located from the difference Fourier maps, but it was not possible to refine their positional parameters. This is due to the disorder inherent to this type of structure. Indeed, multiple weak electron density maxima were found around the water oxygen atoms. XRPD data were collected at room temperature on a Bruker D8 Advanced System with monochromatic Cu radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å).

elements.content:
Thermal Analysis. Combined TG/DTA analysis was performed between 25 and 550 °C, in air on a Netzsch STA 449C apparatus.

Magnetic Measurements. Magnetic susceptibility measurements in the 1.72−300 K temperature range were determined by using a Quantum Design SQUID magnetometer (type MPMS-5) at the W. Trzebiatowski Institute for Low Temperature and Structure Research PAS, Wroclaw. The SQUID magnetometer was calibrated with the palladium rod sample (Materials Research Corporation, measured purity 99.9985%), for which the gram magnetic susceptibility was taken as 5.25 × 10-6 cm3 g-1 at 298 K (National Bureau of Standards, USA). All susceptibility measurements were made at a field of 5 kG. The correction for the diamagnetism of the constituent atoms was calculated by using the Pascal constant.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analysis. Combined TG/DTA analysis was performed between 25 and 550 °C, in air on a Netzsch STA 449C apparatus. 

 Magnetic Measurements. Magnetic susceptibility measurements in the 1.72-300 K temperature range were determined by using a Quantum Design SQUID magnetometer (type MPMS-5) at the W. Trzebiatowski Institute for Low Temperature and Structure Research PAS, Wroclaw. The SQUID magnetometer was calibrated with the palladium rod sample (Materials Research Corporation, measured purity 99.9985%), for which the gram magnetic susceptibility was taken as 5.25 × 10-6 cm3 g-1 at 298 K (National Bureau of Standards, USA). All susceptibility measurements were made at a field of 5 kG. The correction for the diamagnetism of the constituent atoms was calculated by using the Pascal constant.

elements.content: Description of the Metal Organic Framework. Each erbium cation is coordinated by eight oxygen atoms, two of which belong to two water molecules, while the remaining six belong to five fumarate ligands. There are two crystallographically independent fumarate dianions in the structure with dinstinct crystal engineering functions. One of them is quasi planar and acts exclusively in the bis-bidentate bridging mode. As a consequence, quasi planar sheets containing arrays of metals parallel to the ac plane are formed. The second type of fumarate is planar centrosymmetric and acts exclusively in the bis-chelating mode. This ligand is approximately perpendicular to the ac plane, pillaring the sheets between them. As a consequence, large channels filled with water molecules are formed in the direction of the a (9.3 × 9.7 Å2, Figure ) and c (8.5 × 9.3 Å2, Figure ) axes. The question that arises is whether pillaring can also be accomplished by other linear unsaturated ligands, offering the opportunity to synthesize similar solids with variable porosity.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

 Description of the Metal Organic Framework. Each erbium cation is coordinated by eight oxygen atoms, two of which belong to two water molecules, while the remaining six belong to five fumarate ligands. There are two crystallographically independent fumarate dianions in the structure with dinstinct crystal engineering functions. One of them is quasi planar and acts exclusively in the bis-bidentate bridging mode. As a consequence, quasi planar sheets containing arrays of metals parallel to the ac plane are formed. The second type of fumarate is planar centrosymmetric and acts exclusively in the bis-chelating mode. This ligand is approximately perpendicular to the ac plane, pillaring the sheets between them. As a consequence, large channels filled with water molecules are formed in the direction of the a (9.3 × 9.7 Å2, Figure ) and c (8.5 × 9.3 Å2, Figure ) axes. The question that arises is whether pillaring can also be accomplished by other linear unsaturated ligands, offering the opportunity to synthesize similar solids with variable porosity.

elements.content: View of the structure alonga. The bis-chelating pillaring ligand links the layers between them. The coordinated water molecules point into the channel. Lattice water molecules are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 1  View of the structure alonga. The bis-chelating pillaring ligand links the layers between them. The coordinated water molecules point into the channel. Lattice water molecules are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: View of the structure alongc. Lattice water molecules are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 2  View of the structure alongc. Lattice water molecules are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: Structure of the Water Network. The enclathrated and coordinated water molecules are self-assembled through hydrogen bonds along the a and c axes to form a complex 2D infinite network. The hydrogen bonding geometry and the water network are shown in Table and Figure , respectively. For reasons explained below, most of the hydrogen atoms should be disordered. The network is built-up of hexamers with boat or centrosymmetric chair conformation and centrosymmetric cyclic decamers with a BCB conformation. In the case of boat-like hexamers, one of the oxygen atoms (O1w) is also connected through an additional hydrogen bond to the coordinated water molecule O6w (O1w−O6w = 2.766 Å). The latter is at a distance of 3.047 Å from the O3w atom of the same hexagonal ring, with an O1w−O6w−O3w angle of 96.39°. However, the O4w−O3w−O6w and O5w−O3w−O6w angles have the values of 65.65° and 144.64°, respectively, reasonably excluding any appreciable O3w···O6w hydrogen bond interaction. For all hydrogen bonds (Table ), the average O···O distance is 2.86 Å, which is closer to the respective distance of liquid water (2.85 Å)17 than to that of hexagonal or cubic ice (2.762 Å). The angles O−O−O vary from 80° up to 132° approximately with an average of 110°, close to the value of 109.3° found in hexagonal ice (I h).
elements.clean_text: Structure of the Water Network. The enclathrated and coordinated water molecules are self-assembled through hydrogen bonds along the a and c axes to form a complex 2D infinite network. The hydrogen bonding geometry and the water network are shown in Table  and Figure , respectively. For reasons explained below, most of the hydrogen atoms should be disordered. The network is built-up of hexamers with boat or  centrosymmetric chair conformation and centrosymmetric cyclic decamers with a BCB conformation. In the case of boat-like hexamers, one of the oxygen atoms (O1w) is also connected through an additional hydrogen bond to the coordinated water molecule O6w (O1w-O6w = 2.766 Å). The latter is at a distance of 3.047 Å from the O3w atom of the same hexagonal ring, with an O1w-O6w-O3w angle of 96.39°. However, the O4w-O3w-O6w and O5w-O3w-O6w angles have the values of 65.65° and 144.64°, respectively, reasonably excluding any appreciable O3w⋅⋅⋅O6w hydrogen bond interaction. For all hydrogen bonds (Table ), the average O⋅⋅⋅O distance is 2.86 Å, which is closer to the respective distance of liquid water (2.85 Å)17 than to that of hexagonal or cubic ice (2.762 Å). The angles O-O-O vary from 80° up to 132° approximately with an average of 110°, close to the value of 109.3° found in hexagonal ice (I h).

elements.content: (a) Structure of the hydrogen bonded water network projected along theb axis:  (I) hexamers with the chair conformation, (II) hexamers with the boat conformation, (III) decamers with the boat−chair−boat conformation. The pillaring fumarate dianion goes through the center of the decamer. (b) Another view of the three water rings.

The pillaring fumarate dianion goes through the center of the decamer. (b) Another view of the three water rings.

The existence of centrosymmetrically related hydrogen-bonded chair-like hexamers brings about disordering of most of the hydrogen atoms. If one of these atoms acts as hydrogen bond donor, then its symmetry related partner should also donate back a hydrogen atom. The resulting tandem hydrogen bond is highly improbable and its existence has never been proved. More stable configurations are obtained if the hydrogen atoms get disordered over two equally occupated sites so that only one hydrogen atom be involved in a given hydrogen bond. This was obvious in our difference Fourier maps (see Experimental Section), but it was not possible to refine the hydrogen occupation factor, as in a previous example with 1D hydrogen-bonded water chains.
elements.clean_text: The existence of centrosymmetrically related hydrogen-bonded chair-like hexamers brings about disordering of most of the hydrogen atoms. If one of these atoms acts as hydrogen bond donor, then its symmetry related partner should also donate back a hydrogen atom. The resulting tandem hydrogen bond is highly improbable and its existence has never been proved. More stable configurations are obtained if the hydrogen atoms get disordered over two equally occupated sites so that only one hydrogen atom be involved in a given hydrogen bond. This was obvious in our difference Fourier maps (see Experimental Section), but it was not possible to refine the hydrogen occupation factor, as in a previous example with 1D hydrogen-bonded water chains.

elements.content: Two-dimensional water structures have been found in some inorganic and organic hydrates, but this structure has some unique features. The boat-like hexameric units propagate along the c axis through edge-sharing, mimicking the structure of ice I h along its c axis. The resulting tapes are linked through fused hexameric units with chair conformation. As far as we know, apart from ice I h, this is the first time that both chair and boat conformations are found in the same structure. Water layers consisting of boat-like hexamers, mimicking the ac plane of ice I h, have been found in an inorganic hydrate. Chair-like hexamers were found recently in a cobalt cage complex. The voids formed in this structure are filled with decameric water clusters that mimic the structure of cubic ice. Tapes consisting of fused four- and six-membered chair-like water rings were found recently in the channels of an organic molecular crystal. Finally, ice-like edge-sharing O8 cages were observed in the structure of a cadmium terephthalate hydrate. The formation of cyclic water decamers has never been reported before. Discrete cage-like water decamers in the gas phase have been recently studied spectroscopically. A similar cage-like decamer was also formed in the cavities of an organic supramolecular complex between 5-hydroxisophthalic acid and [18]crown-6 ether. The formation of the present cyclic decamer is certainly related to the well-known effect of hydrophobic hydration, responsible for the formation of the 3D gas clathrate hydrates. Indeed, the pillaring organic ligands pass through the center of the decamer rings to connect the adjacent metal−organic layers. Therefore, it is reasonable to suppose that the repulsion experienced by the surrounding water molecules during the initial growth process leads to the formation of the cyclic decamer, offering the pattern of a 2D clathrate hydrate. It is worth noting that the cyclic decamer adopts the BCB conformation (Figure b) and may be considered as the simplest supramolecular analogue of the BCB cyclodecane.

elements.content: It is also worth mentioning that the only links (apart from a weak O2w−O2 contact of 3.066 Å) of the water network to the MOF are the coordinated water molecules O5w and O6w. The FT-IR spectra (Figure a) in the region of the νOH vibrations (3000−4000 cm-1) are in line with the aforementioned water network. There is a broad band exhibiting three distinct peaks at 3517, 3371, and 3240 cm-1. The first one is close to the value of 3490 cm-1 reported for liquid water, while the third peak is between ice (3220 cm-1) and liquid water (3280 cm-1). It is interesting to note that in a recent report of a spectroscopic study of water clusters formed in liquid helium, the authors stated that a weak peak (Figure in ref b) at about 3230 cm-1 might be associated with clusters containing more than six water molecules. The peak at 3371 cm-1 is close to 3335 cm-1 reported for the cyclic hexamer formed in liquid helium.
elements.clean_text: It is also worth mentioning that the only links (apart from a weak O2w-O2 contact of 3.066 Å) of the water network to the MOF are the coordinated water molecules O5w and O6w. There is a broad band exhibiting three distinct peaks at 3517, 3371, and 3240 cm-1. The first one is close to the value of 3490 cm-1 reported for liquid water, while the third peak is between ice (3220 cm-1) and liquid water (3280 cm-1). It is interesting to note that in a recent report  of a spectroscopic study of water clusters formed in liquid helium, the authors stated that a weak peak (Figure  in ref b) at about 3230 cm-1 might be associated with clusters containing more than six water molecules. The peak at 3371 cm-1 is close to 3335 cm-1 reported for the cyclic hexamer formed in liquid helium.

elements.content: Thermal Analysis, Water Sorption, and XRPD Patterns. Combined TG/DTA analysis was carried out in air on powder samples of 1. A first endothermic weight loss of 22.91% corresponding to the departure of all water molecules (theor. 24.19%) was observed between 50 and 160 °C (Figure ). No noticeable weight loss was then observed until 400 °C, beyond which decomposition occurs. In a separate experiment, a sample of 1 was heated in air at 90 °C for about 90 min and then was subjected to TG/DTA analysis. To avoid (as much as possible) rapid initial uptake of water from the ambient humidity, the “evacuated” sample was first heated at 90 °C, for some minutes, in the TG apparatus, cooled to the ambient temperature, and then heated again. Under these conditions (Figure ), a weight loss of 3.58% was observed between 80 and 140 °C, corresponding to about 1.5 (theor. 3.85%) water molecules per formula unit. We therefore formulate the evacuated solid as Er2(fum)3·xH2O, 2, (x between 0 and 1.5). To ensure that x will remain within the limits indicated, compound 2 was always heated for about 1 h at 90 °C before each experiment.
elements.clean_text: Thermal Analysis, Water Sorption, and XRPD Patterns. Combined TG/DTA analysis was carried out in air on powder samples of 1. A first endothermic weight loss of 22.91% corresponding to the departure of all water molecules (theor. 24.19%) was observed between 50 and 160 °C (Figure ). No noticeable weight loss was then observed until 400 °C, beyond which decomposition occurs. In a separate experiment, a sample of 1 was heated in air at 90 °C for about 90 min and then was subjected to TG/DTA analysis. To avoid (as much as possible) rapid initial uptake of water from the ambient humidity, the "evacuated" sample was first heated at 90 °C, for some minutes, in the TG apparatus, cooled to the ambient temperature, and then heated again. Under these conditions (Figure ), a weight loss of 3.58% was observed between 80 and 140 °C, corresponding to about 1.5 (theor. 3.85%) water molecules per formula unit. We therefore formulate the evacuated solid as Er2(fum)3⋅xH2O, 2, (x between 0 and 1.5). To ensure that x will remain within the limits indicated, compound 2 was always heated for about 1 h at 90 °C before each experiment.

elements.content: Some investigations of the sorption capability of 2 were also carried out. Compound 2 was immersed in liquid water or ethanol overnight or was exposed to water vapors for 48 h at room temperature, and the resulting samples were subjected to TG/DTA and XRPD (X-ray powder diffraction) (Figures and , respectively). The thermal analysis curves for the samples immersed in liquid water or exposed to water vapors show endothermic weight loss of 23.84 and 21.68%, respectively, between 50 and 160 °C. Moreover, the XRPD patterns (Figure ) are identical to that of 1, concluding that the departure of water from 1 is a reversible process. This is also supported from the microanalysis results (see Experimental Section). The sample immersed in ethanol shows an endothermic weight loss of 10.73% between 50 and 100 °C. However, the examination of the IR spectra (Figure ) showed that the strong νco peak of ethanol around 1050 cm-1   28 is completely absent, indicating that the desorbed guest is water and not ethanol. The observed weight loss of 10.73% corresponds to 4.5 water molecules per formula unit (theor. 10.68%), and the new hydrate may be formulated as Er2(fum)3·4.5H2O, 3. The microanalysis results also agree well with this interpretation (see Experimental Section). In this case, the appearance of the broad band centered around 3346 cm-1 is due to water molecules. Further support of this hypothesis is provided by comparing the XRPD patterns of 1, 2, and 3 (Figure ). We may remark that the most prominent peak of 1 is due to the (020) reflection. The strength of this reflection is due to the electron density of the channel walls of the layerlike compound 1. The peaks of 3 are broader than those of 1, indicating poor crystallinity. However, the patterns of 1 and 3 are similar, showing that the structures of the two compounds are essentially the same. We may observe that the (020) reflection is still the predominant one, establishing with certainty the periodicity along the interlayer direction. The peaks in 2 are even broader than those of 3, but we can still recognize four low indice prominent peaks in the region 10° < 2θ < 15°. The similarity with the patterns of 1 and 3 is obvious, albeit the first peak of 2 is displaced toward higher 2θ values. It is reasonable to suppose that upon progressive dehydration of 1, there is progressive deformation of the structure and, conversely, upon hydration there is progressive restauration of the initial structure. If this is true, then the chemical connectivity within the framework will remain essentially the same during the above-mentioned transformation. Indeed, the IR spectra (Figure ) in the region of the stretching vibration of the carboxylate group (1700−1300 cm-1) for 1, 2, and 3 are essentially the same. This is an indication that there is no significant modification of the coordination mode of the carboxylate groups. It is well-known that the difference Δ between the asymmetric stretching vibration and the symmetric one (Δ = νas − νsym) depends on the coordination mode of the carboxylate group. The value of Δ is well below 200 cm-1 (160, 139, and 178 cm-1 for 1, 3, and 2, respectively) and is compatible with the bridging or “symmetric” chelating coordination modes of the carboxylate group. The broadness of the two peaks suggests that both modes are present. This interpretation fits quite well with the results of the crystal structure of 1. This preference for the water seems to support the idea that the water network is closely related to the formation of the MOF. We may remark that all coordinated water molecules (Figure ) point inside the channels and may act as templates for attracting other water molecules.

The thermal analysis curves for the samples immersed in liquid water or exposed to water vapors  show endothermic weight loss of 23.84 and 21.68%, respectively, between 50 and 160 °C. Moreover, the XRPD patterns (Figure ) are identical to that of 1, concluding that the departure of water from 1 is a reversible process. However, the examination of the IR spectra (Figure ) showed that the strong νco peak of ethanol around 1050 cm-1              28 is completely absent, indicating that the desorbed guest is water and not ethanol. The observed weight loss of 10.73% corresponds to 4.5 water molecules per formula unit (theor. 10.68%), and the new hydrate may be formulated as Er2(fum)3⋅4.5H2O, 3. elements.content: Magnetic Susceptibility Measurements. The planar conformation of the ligand and the presence of metal arrays bridged by the carboxylate groups encouraged us to proceed to magnetic characterization of compound 1 and of the evacuated compound 2. The experimental χEr [being the molar magnetic susceptibility per Er(III)] and χEr T vs T plots of 1 are shown in Figure a. The room temperature, χEr T value (10.76 cm3 K mol-1) is close to that (11.48 cm3 K mol-1) expected 30 for a free Er(III) ion. Upon cooling, χEr T decreases slightly up to ca. 45 K, where upon it decreases more rapidly, reaching 6.81 cm3 K mol-1 at 1.9 K. In the 300−1.9 K temperature range, the magnetic susceptibility data of 1 could be described by a Curie−Weiss law with Curie, C, and Weiss constant, θ values of 10.5 cm3 K mol-1 and −1.06 K, respectively. The corresponding values in the 50−300 K temperature range are 10.8 cm3 K mol-1 and −2.11 K, respectively. The situation is analogous for 2:  its χEr vs T and χEr T vs T plots are shown in Figure b. The room temperature χEr T value of 10.37 cm3 K mol-1 is slightly lower than that of 1; still it declines more drastically as T decreases up to ca. 50 K, whereupon it decreases more rapidly, reaching 5.18 cm3 K mol-1 at 1.9 K. The Curie and Weiss constant values of 2 are C = 9.80 cm3 K mol-1 and θ = −2.19 K, respectively (for the 300−1.9 K temperature range), and 10.6 cm3 K mol-1 and −6.77 K, respectively (for the 50−300 K temperature range). In both cases, the average value of χEr T at room temperature is, as expected, close to what is predicted in the free-ion approximation. Interpretation of the experimental data, however, remains difficult, due to the lack of proper theoretical fitting models for the three-dimensional structurally characterized 1, and the lack of X-ray structural data for 2. Nevertheless, both the decrease of the χEr T experimental value as T decreases, and the negative θ values calculated for both complexes, could be attributed to weak antiferromagnetic interactions, appearing stronger in 2.

elements.content: (a) The magnetic susceptibility χEr (·) and χEr T (○) vs T for Er2(fum)3·12H2O, (1); (b) The magnetic susceptibility χEr (·) and χEr T (○) vs T for Er2(fum)3·xH2O (0 < x <1.5) (2).

elements.content: Five tables containing complete information on data collection and refinement for 1, final atomic coordinates, anisotropic thermal parameters, all bond lengths, and angles. X-ray crystallographic information file (CIF) is available for 1. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text:
Supporting Information Available 

Five tables containing complete information on data collection and refinement for 1, final atomic coordinates, anisotropic thermal parameters, all bond lengths, and angles. X-ray crystallographic information file (CIF) is available for 1. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

elements.content: <title>References</title>
elements.clean_text: References

cln_elements.content: [Er 2 (fum) 3 (H 2 O) 4 ]·8H 2 O (1) . Single crystals were obtained by diffusing an aqueous solution of 0.007 M erbium nitrate in a silica gel column containing the ligand (0.01 M) at pH approximately 6. The test tube containing the reacting system was left open, and, after several weeks, upon complete evaporation of the liquid phase, one single crystal of pink color was formed. The composition of the crystal was deduced from X-ray crystallography. The same crystalline phase was easily prepared in powder form by mixing 30 mL of 0.1 M fumaric acid at pH 6.1 with 20 mL of 0.1 M erbium nitrate. The final pH was approximately 5. The pink precipitate was washed with distilled water and left to dry in air. The experimental XRPD pattern was in good agreement with that simulated from the single crystal data. Elemental analysis calcd (%) for 1 in powder form:  C 16.13, H 3.36; found:  C 16.18, H 3.39.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 [Er  2  (fum)  3  (H  2  O)  4  ]⋅8H  2  O (1) . Single crystals were obtained by diffusing an aqueous solution of 0.007 M erbium nitrate in a silica gel column containing the ligand (0.01 M) at pH approximately 6. The test tube containing the reacting system was left open, and, after several weeks, upon complete evaporation of the liquid phase, one single crystal of pink color was formed. The composition of the crystal was deduced from X-ray crystallography. The same crystalline phase was easily prepared in powder form by mixing 30 mL of 0.1 M fumaric acid at pH 6.1 with 20 mL of 0.1 M erbium nitrate. The final pH was approximately 5. The pink precipitate was washed with distilled water and left to dry in air. The experimental XRPD pattern was in good agreement with that simulated from the single crystal data. Elemental analysis calcd (%) for 1 in powder form: C 16.13, H 3.36; found: C 16.18, H 3.39.

other properties: The experimental XRPD pattern was in good agreement with that simulated from the single crystal data.

cln_elements.content:
Thermal Analysis, Water Sorption, and XRPD Patterns. Combined TG/DTA analysis was carried out in air on powder samples of 1. A first endothermic weight loss of 22.91% corresponding to the departure of all water molecules (theor. 24.19%) was observed between 50 and 160 °C (Figure ). No noticeable weight loss was then observed until 400 °C, beyond which decomposition occurs. In a separate experiment, a sample of 1 was heated in air at 90 °C for about 90 min and then was subjected to TG/DTA analysis. To avoid (as much as possible) rapid initial uptake of water from the ambient humidity, the “evacuated” sample was first heated at 90 °C, for some minutes, in the TG apparatus, cooled to the ambient temperature, and then heated again. Under these conditions (Figure ), a weight loss of 3.58% was observed between 80 and 140 °C, corresponding to about 1.5 (theor. 3.85%) water molecules per formula unit. We therefore formulate the evacuated solid as Er2(fum)3·xH2O, 2, (x between 0 and 1.5). To ensure that x will remain within the limits indicated, compound 2 was always heated for about 1 h at 90 °C before each experiment.

Some investigations of the sorption capability of 2 were also carried out. Compound 2 was immersed in liquid water or ethanol overnight or was exposed to water vapors for 48 h at room temperature, and the resulting samples were subjected to TG/DTA and XRPD (X-ray powder diffraction) (Figures and , respectively). The thermal analysis curves for the samples immersed in liquid water or exposed to water vapors show endothermic weight loss of 23.84 and 21.68%, respectively, between 50 and 160 °C. Moreover, the XRPD patterns (Figure ) are identical to that of 1, concluding that the departure of water from 1 is a reversible process. This is also supported from the microanalysis results (see Experimental Section). The sample immersed in ethanol shows an endothermic weight loss of 10.73% between 50 and 100 °C. However, the examination of the IR spectra (Figure ) showed that the strong νco peak of ethanol around 1050 cm-1   28 is completely absent, indicating that the desorbed guest is water and not ethanol. The observed weight loss of 10.73% corresponds to 4.5 water molecules per formula unit (theor. 10.68%), and the new hydrate may be formulated as Er2(fum)3·4.5H2O, 3. The microanalysis results also agree well with this interpretation (see Experimental Section). In this case, the appearance of the broad band centered around 3346 cm-1 is due to water molecules. Further support of this hypothesis is provided by comparing the XRPD patterns of 1, 2, and 3 (Figure ). We may remark that the most prominent peak of 1 is due to the (020) reflection. The strength of this reflection is due to the electron density of the channel walls of the layerlike compound 1. The peaks of 3 are broader than those of 1, indicating poor crystallinity. However, the patterns of 1 and 3 are similar, showing that the structures of the two compounds are essentially the same. We may observe that the (020) reflection is still the predominant one, establishing with certainty the periodicity along the interlayer direction. The peaks in 2 are even broader than those of 3, but we can still recognize four low indice prominent peaks in the region 10° < 2θ < 15°. The similarity with the patterns of 1 and 3 is obvious, albeit the first peak of 2 is displaced toward higher 2θ values. It is reasonable to suppose that upon progressive dehydration of 1, there is progressive deformation of the structure and, conversely, upon hydration there is progressive restauration of the initial structure. If this is true, then the chemical connectivity within the framework will remain essentially the same during the above-mentioned transformation. Indeed, the IR spectra (Figure ) in the region of the stretching vibration of the carboxylate group (1700−1300 cm-1) for 1, 2, and 3 are essentially the same. This is an indication that there is no significant modification of the coordination mode of the carboxylate groups. It is well-known that the difference Δ between the asymmetric stretching vibration and the symmetric one (Δ = νas − νsym) depends on the coordination mode of the carboxylate group. The value of Δ is well below 200 cm-1 (160, 139, and 178 cm-1 for 1, 3, and 2, respectively) and is compatible with the bridging or “symmetric” chelating coordination modes of the carboxylate group. The broadness of the two peaks suggests that both modes are present. This interpretation fits quite well with the results of the crystal structure of 1. This preference for the water seems to support the idea that the water network is closely related to the formation of the MOF. We may remark that all coordinated water molecules (Figure ) point inside the channels and may act as templates for attracting other water molecules.

Magnetic Susceptibility Measurements. The planar conformation of the ligand and the presence of metal arrays bridged by the carboxylate groups encouraged us to proceed to magnetic characterization of compound 1 and of the evacuated compound 2. The experimental χEr [being the molar magnetic susceptibility per Er(III)] and χEr T vs T plots of 1 are shown in Figure a. The room temperature, χEr T value (10.76 cm3 K mol-1) is close to that (11.48 cm3 K mol-1) expected 30 for a free Er(III) ion. Upon cooling, χEr T decreases slightly up to ca. 45 K, where upon it decreases more rapidly, reaching 6.81 cm3 K mol-1 at 1.9 K. In the 300−1.9 K temperature range, the magnetic susceptibility data of 1 could be described by a Curie−Weiss law with Curie, C, and Weiss constant, θ values of 10.5 cm3 K mol-1 and −1.06 K, respectively. The corresponding values in the 50−300 K temperature range are 10.8 cm3 K mol-1 and −2.11 K, respectively. The situation is analogous for 2:  its χEr vs T and χEr T vs T plots are shown in Figure b. The room temperature χEr T value of 10.37 cm3 K mol-1 is slightly lower than that of 1; still it declines more drastically as T decreases up to ca. 50 K, whereupon it decreases more rapidly, reaching 5.18 cm3 K mol-1 at 1.9 K. The Curie and Weiss constant values of 2 are C = 9.80 cm3 K mol-1 and θ = −2.19 K, respectively (for the 300−1.9 K temperature range), and 10.6 cm3 K mol-1 and −6.77 K, respectively (for the 50−300 K temperature range). In both cases, the average value of χEr T at room temperature is, as expected, close to what is predicted in the free-ion approximation. Interpretation of the experimental data, however, remains difficult, due to the lack of proper theoretical fitting models for the three-dimensional structurally characterized 1, and the lack of X-ray structural data for 2. Nevertheless, both the decrease of the χEr T experimental value as T decreases, and the negative θ values calculated for both complexes, could be attributed to weak antiferromagnetic interactions, appearing stronger in 2.

cln_elements.content: View of the structure alonga. The bis-chelating pillaring ligand links the layers between them. The coordinated water molecules point into the channel. Lattice water molecules are omitted for clarity.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  View of the structure alonga. The bis-chelating pillaring ligand links the layers between them. The coordinated water molecules point into the channel. Lattice water molecules are omitted for clarity.

cln_elements.content: View of the structure alongc. Lattice water molecules are omitted for clarity.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  View of the structure alongc. Lattice water molecules are omitted for clarity.

cln_elements.content: (a) Structure of the hydrogen bonded water network projected along theb axis:  (I) hexamers with the chair conformation, (II) hexamers with the boat conformation, (III) decamers with the boat−chair−boat conformation. The pillaring fumarate dianion goes through the center of the decamer. (b) Another view of the three water rings.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Structure of the hydrogen bonded water network projected along theb axis: (I) hexamers with the chair conformation, (II) hexamers with the boat conformation, (III) decamers with the boat-chair-boat conformation. The pillaring fumarate dianion goes through the center of the decamer. (b) Another view of the three water rings.

metadata.title:
Cyclic Water Hexamers and Decamers in a Porous
Lanthanide−Organic Framework:  Correlation between
